Description: Inlaid glazed composition tile: in the form of a plumed cartouche containing the throne and birth names of Sety II. It is in blue on a white background and wears a headdress of two plumes and a sun-disk in yellow. The back is flat and in part unglazed.
Curator's comments: Glazed tiles survive from several New Kingdom palaces, including those of Sety I at Qantir and Ramses III at Tell el-Yahudiya, and in the cultic palace complex of Medinet Habu at western Thebes. This royal cartouche is a decorative element, not part of an inscription. Published: R. Parkinson, ‘ Cracking Codes: The Rosetta Stone and Decipherment’ (London, 1999), cat 31e, p. 109. Bibliography: I. Freestone and D. Gaimster (eds), 'Pottery in the Making:World Ceramic Traditions' (London, 1997), 106, fig. 2.
Bibliographic references: Parkinson 1999 / Cracking Codes: The Rosetta Stone and Decipherment (31e)
